item.title: Fear Sharpens in Japan That Hiroshima’s Lessons Are Fading
item.media:description: The Atomic Bomb Dome in the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park on Wednesday.
item.description: As President Obama prepares to visit, the Asian country’s aversion to war is being challenged by a conservative movement led by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: In Obama’s Visit to Hiroshima, a Complex Calculus of Asian Politics
item.media:description: President Obama in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Monday. Mr. Obama this week lifted a decades-old embargo on military sales. He will visit Hiroshima, Japan, on Friday, where the United States dropped an atomic bomb 71 years ago.
item.description: The president’s visit to Vietnam and particularly Japan highlights old grievances as well as the current power struggles among nations big and small in Asia.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Korean Survivors of Atomic Bombs Renew Fight for Recognition, and Apology
item.media:description: Kim Il-jo, 88, in her room in Hapcheon, South Korea. Survivors who returned to South Korea were shunned and denied care, partly to preserve the official view that the nuclear attacks were necessary to liberate Korea.
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.description: Survivors of the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombings have argued that the United States will have moral authority only after it apologizes for the “original sin.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. Says Its Strikes Are Hitting More Significant ISIS Targets
item.media:description: A Navy air crew after a mission over Iraq last year.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: Military officials say they have improved intelligence and a disjointed process for identifying targets, and are now hitting oil facilities and secret cash coffers.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Pakistan Finally Confirms Taliban Leader’s Death in U.S. Strike
item.description: An adviser to the prime minister said the American drone strike that killed Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour was a violation of Pakistan’s sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Muslim Boys at a Swiss School Must Shake Teachers’ Hands, Even Female Ones
item.description: School authorities in the town of Therwil said the family of two Syrian brothers could be fined about $5,000 if the teenagers refused to shake their female teacher’s hand on religious grounds.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: As ‘Brexit’ Vote Nears, British Data Shows Increase in Immigration
item.media:description: Supporters of the U.K. Independence Party campaigned in Dagenham, England, this week against continued membership in the European Union.
item.description: Campaigners to leave the European Union seized on the yearly net increase of 20,000, arguing that membership made it impossible to control population flows.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Have You Voted for a Far-Right Party in Europe? Share Your Thoughts
item.media:description: Supporters of the far-right Freedom Party at a rally in Vienna last month.
item.description: The Times is collecting the personal experiences of voters who have backed those groups. Whom did you support? What motivated you?
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Last Liberia Sanctions, Vestige of Civil War, Are Lifted
item.description: A resolution by the United Nations Security Council to lift the remaining sanctions will enable Liberia to buy arms on the global market.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Body Count Points to a Mexican Military Out of Control
item.media:description: In a 2011 shootout in Yurécuaro, Mexican soldiers killed four men said to be members of a drug gang. A bystander was also killed, the local news media reported.
item.description: The statistics on deaths, which the government has stopped reporting, offer a rare glimpse into the Mexican military’s role in the war on organized crime.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Report Warns of Climate Change Disasters That Rival Hollywood’s
item.media:description: Stonehenge, Salisbury, England.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: A joint report released by Unesco, the United Nations Environment Program and the Union of Concerned Scientists detailed the threat climate change could pose to World Heritage sites on five continents.
item.dc:creator: JONAH BROMWICH
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: U.N. Suspends Torture Inquiry in Ukraine
item.description: Agency investigators left the country a day early after being denied access to sites under control of the domestic intelligence agency, the team’s leader said.
item.dc:creator: ALISA SOPOVA
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Okinawa Murder Case Tests U.S.-Japan Ties Before Obama Visit
item.description: The arrest of an American in connection with the killing of a Japanese woman has escalated into a crisis that may complicate the Pentagon’s operations in Okinawa.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: U.S. Commandos Work With Syrian Fighters in Push Toward ISIS Stronghold
item.media:description: American Special Operations forces, photographed Wednesday in the village of Fatisah, pushed closer to Raqqa, the Islamic State’s de facto capital in northern Syria.
item.description: Pentagon officials said the Americans were not involved in any combat role, despite photographs that showed commandos assisting fighters during their offensive against the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Trilobites: Frogs That Escaped Extinction
item.media:description: A single long exposure photograph of an Amazon gladiator frog in Panama in March 2015.
item.description: Robin Moore takes photos he hopes will highlight the plight of amphibian species worldwide, 40 percent of which are threatened.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: Obama Admits World Leaders ‘Rattled’ by Donald Trump
item.description: “I think it’s fair to say that they are surprised by the Republican nominee; they are not sure how seriously to take some of his pronouncements,” Mr. Obama said in Shima, Japan.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: At Hiroshima, Obama Faces Difficult Choices
item.media:description: The Hiroshima Peace Memorial on Tuesday.
item.description: More than 70 years later, the bombing still evokes powerful emotions and the visit will not make everyone happy.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Uffizi, With Indiana University, Will Digitize Ancient Sculptures
item.media:description: Hannah Rawcliffe, a doctoral student at Indiana University, photographing the Uffizi Gallery’s collection of ancient Greek and Roman statuary, to eventually create high-resolution 3-D models.
item.description: The 3-D models are expected to provide information on the state of the statues and past restorations and allow for new studies to be carried out.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Shiraz Journal: End of an Art Form? The Persian Rug May Not Be Long for This World
item.media:description: Nomads and others at a carpet production center owned by a family of carpet traders outside Shiraz.
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.description: Shoppers’ changing tastes, and years of economic sanctions, are putting in jeopardy one of the world’s most complex and labor-intensive handicrafts.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Obama, in Japan, Emphasizes Lingering Threat of Nuclear War
item.description: The president said that Hiroshima was not just a reminder of the toll of World War II, but also that “that the job’s not done in reducing conflict.”
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Sinosphere: Bus Project Finds a Way Around China’s Traffic Jams: Gliding Above Them
item.description: The designer of the vehicle, Song Youzhou, says that prototypes are being constructed and that five cities have signed contracts with his company for pilot projects.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FENG

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Ben Hillman and Gray Tuttle on Ethnic Unrest in Xinjiang and Tibet
item.media:description: Chinese soldiers patrolling the streets of Urumqi, the capital of the Xinjiang Uighur Autonomous Region, in July 2009, after a protest over a fatal shooting of two Uighurs in southern China escalated into riots that killed at least 197 people.
item.description: In an interview, Mr. Hillman and Mr. Tuttle discussed the grievances behind recent protests and the likelihood of their resolution.
item.dc:creator: EMILY FENG and EDWARD WONG

item.title: Azerbaijan Frees Khadija Ismayilova, Journalist Who Exposed Official Corruption
item.media:description: Azeri Khadija Ismayilova spoke to the media after she was released in Baku, Azerbaijan, on Wednesday.
item.description: The release of Ms. Ismayilova was welcomed by international rights groups after her incarceration had become an embarrassment to Azerbaijan’s president.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: U.S. Urges No Bail for Reza Zarrab in Iran Sanctions Case
item.media:description: Reza Zarrab in Istanbul in 2013.
item.description: Federal prosecutors said Mr. Zarrab, a prominent Turkish-based gold trader who is jailed in New York, was a flight risk.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: EgyptAir Enlists European Companies to Look for Black Boxes From Flight 804
item.description: The plane’s cockpit data and voice recorders are believed to be lying on the edge of the range for hearing and locating their signals.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Toronto on the Lookout for 2 Escapees — Rodents From a Zoo
item.media:description: A capybara in Venezuela.
item.description: Two capybaras, the world’s largest rodent, were still missing more than 24 hours after breaking out of a small zoo on the city’s west end.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Hamas Calls for Resumption of Death Penalty in Gaza
item.description: Several Palestinians convicted of murder or of collaborating with Israel face execution after the call by Hamas, the militant group that rules Gaza.
item.dc:creator: MAJD AL WAHEIDI and DIAA HADID

item.title: Gas Runs Low in France as Protesters Block Refineries in Labor Battle
item.description: An intensifying fight over labor law changes led to long gasoline lines, and in some places the government used force to disperse protesters.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Bangladeshi Police Dismiss Claim That ISIS Was Behind Shop Owner’s Death
item.description: The police have arrested a former customer of the victim, a Hindu shoe store owner, but an account linked to Islamic militants claimed responsibility for the death.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Johnny Depp and Australia’s Agriculture Minister in a Feud With Legs
item.media:description: Johnny Depp arriving in court in Australia in April.
item.description: The feud between the actor and the minister has gotten stranger, a year after Mr. Depp and his wife caused a kerfuffle over their dogs.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Afghan Lovers Begin an Asylum Odyssey in New York
item.media:description: Zakia and Mohammad Ali and their 17-month-old daughter, Ruqia, on a train after arriving at John F. Kennedy Airport in New York on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.description: Zakia and Mohammad Ali, whose families oppose their union because they are from different sects, are seeking a new life in the United States.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Paris Bridge of Love Locks Now One of Sculptures
item.media:description: Artwork by Daniel Hourdé at the Pont des Arts in Paris, which used to be lined with locks attached by lovers pledging their fidelity.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: The locks were removed by the city after their weight caused a railing to collapse on the Pont des Arts, where contemporary sculptures by the artist Daniel Hourdé will now reside.
item.dc:creator: BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: Egypt Expels French Journalist in a Rare Move Against Foreign Media
item.description: The journalist, Rémy Pigaglio, worked in Egypt for almost two years and had residency permits and media accreditation that allowed him to do so legally.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Bone Relic From Becket, Murdered Archbishop, to Return to Scene of the Crime
item.media:description: Cardinal Vincent Nichols, the archbishop of Westminster, center, with a bone relic of Thomas Becket during a ceremony at Westminster Cathedral in London on Monday.
item.description: More than eight centuries after the archbishop of Canterbury was killed in the city’s cathedral, what is believed to be a piece of his elbow is traveling from Hungary back to England.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: French Authorities Given Broader Powers to Fight Terrorism
item.media:description: The French National Assembly in Paris on Tuesday. A law approved on Wednesday is the latest in a series of legislative changes that the government in France has pushed through to give authorities greater policing powers.
item.description: A look at how France has reshaped its legal system in response to the attacks that killed 130 people in and around Paris.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Giant Sinkhole Swallows Dozens of Cars in Florence
item.description: A water pipe was said to have compromised a road not far from the city’s historic center; no injuries were reported.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH OLIVENNES

item.title: Sinosphere: Tsai Ing-wen, Taiwan’s First Female Leader, Is Assailed in China for Being ‘Emotional’
item.media:description: President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan speaking at a meeting in Taipei on Wednesday of her Democratic Progressive Party.
item.description: An article by a senior scholar for the People’s Liberation Army said that Tsai Ing-wen was prone to a radical style because she lacked the “burden of love, family and children.”
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ and VANESSA PIAO

item.title: Indonesia Approves Castration for Sex Offenders Who Prey on Children
item.media:description: Suspects in the gang rape and murder of a 14-year-old schoolgirl before their trial in Curup, Bengkulu Province, Indonesia, this month. The seven teenagers were each sentenced to 10 years in prison for the crime.
item.description: The new punishment comes in response to the brutal gang rape and murder in April of a 14-year-old girl on her way home on the island of Sumatra.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Beijing Journal: China’s Leader Wears Many Hats, but Only One Jacket
item.media:description: Mr. Xi visiting the control room of China Central Television in Beijing in February. The jacket he wears conveys a man-in-a-hurry image, with a determined lack of glamour.
item.description: There was the Mao suit. Now there’s the Xi jacket, Xi Jinping’s navy windbreaker that has become a sartorial symbol of his rule.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: ‘Brexit’ Could Spell More Austerity for Britain, Study Warns
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain spoke this month in Oxfordshire, England, in support of staying in the European Union.
item.description: The report from the Institute for Fiscal Studies, a frequent critic of government economic plans, was a boon for Prime Minister David Cameron.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Ukrainian Pilot, Nadiya Savchenko, Is Exchanged for 2 Russian Prisoners
item.media:description: Capt. Yevgeny Yerofeyev, left, and Sgt. Aleksandr Aleksandrov at a hearing in Kiev, Ukraine, in January. The Russian Ministry of Defense has not acknowledged any ties to the two.
item.description: The high-profile inmate swap could help ease negotiations over a settlement in the conflict in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Europe Seeks Greater Control Over Digital Services
item.media:description: Reed Hastings, chief executive of Netflix. The company fears it will be required not only to carry more local content in individual countries but also to help pay for its development.
item.media:credit: Bernd Von Jutrczenka/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: As part of efforts to create a digital single market for online services, the region wants to create rules that would affect companies like Netflix and Facebook.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Craft Breweries Find They May Have a 5,000-Year-Old Relative
item.media:description: Scholars say that beer may have been an important part of ritual feasting in ancient China.
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.description: Researchers have analyzed pottery vessels discovered at a site in Shaanxi Province and determined that they are the first direct evidence of a beer-brewing operation.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences

item.title: Netanyahu Names Avigdor Lieberman Israeli Defense Minister as Party Joins Coalition
item.media:description: Hamas supporters burned pictures of Mr. Lieberman in Gaza City on Friday.
item.description: The nomination was the main condition for adding Yisrael Beiteinu’s seats to Benjamin Netanyahu’s alliance, a move that underlines the government’s hawkish image.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Indonesian Children Face Hazards on Tobacco Farms, Report Says
item.media:description: Children working with tobacco leaves near Surabaya, Indonesia.
item.media:credit: Marcus Bleasdale/Human Rights Watch, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Children as young as 8 working on tobacco farms are exposed to harmful nicotine and pesticides, according to Human Rights Watch researchers.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Obama, Perhaps Slyly, Calls Attention to Vietnam’s Brain Drain
item.media:description: President Obama holding a town-hall-style meeting with members of the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, on Wednesday.
item.description: The American president said Vietnam need not worry about losing talented people, but then he proceeded to describe conditions that fit Vietnam perfectly.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Taliban Name Lesser-Known Cleric as Their New Leader
item.media:description: The Taliban identified the man in this photograph as Mawlawi Haibatullah Akhundzada on Wednesday.
item.description: The insurgency confirmed its former leader’s death in a drone strike, and it said the new one, Mawlawi Haibatullah Akhundzada, would continue the war.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL, TAIMOOR SHAH and ZAHRA NADER

item.title: What in the World: Korean Words, Straight From the Elephant’s Mouth
item.media:credit: Illustrtaion by Leif Parsons / Bernatets Photo / shutterstock.com
item.description: While parrots are supposed to, well, parrot human speech, elephants aren’t. But don’t tell that to Koshik, an Asian elephant at a zoo near Seoul who can say at least five words.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: What in the World: Law and Intestinal Disorder: Police Crack Down on Toxic Food
item.media:credit: Illustration by Antonio de Luca; Photos by Shulevskyy Volodymyr, Nikola Bilic, Rudmer Zwerver, Gayvoronskaya_Yana, Yojik, ConstantinosZ/shutterstock
item.description: Italian olives painted to look greener and sugar cut with fertilizer in Sudan are just two of the illegal products that recent investigations have uncovered.
item.dc:creator: JAKE DOHERTY

item.title: What in the World: Bees Thrive in an Unexpected Paradise: Paris
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photo by EQRoy/shutterstock
item.description: Despite the smog, honeybees live longer and produce more honey in Paris than in the French countryside, one beekeeper says.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Coral vs. Coal
item.media:description: Bleached coral in the Great Barrier Reef.
item.description: The Great Barrier Reef, one of the largest living things on earth, is threatened by global warming. The Australian right is in denial.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Russia: A Nation of Sore Losers
item.description: Moscow’s mantra is that the country is beset by enemies who want to see it fail.
item.dc:creator: MAXIM TRUDOLYUBOV

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: What Is German?
item.media:description: President Joachim Gauck of Germany, center, with local politicians from around the country on Monday.
item.description: The question of national identity is once again on the table, and the far right is setting the tone.
item.dc:creator: ANNA SAUERBREY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
